column2: a former bishopric

column1: The town was historically known as Germanicopolis (Greek: Γερμανικόπολις)
column2: Germanig and possibly Clibanus; which later mutated to Ermenek.

column1: Germanicopolis was an ancient town in the Roman province of Isauria. (Hierocl. p. 709; Concil. Chalced. p. 659; Const. Porphyr. de Them. i. 13.) The city took its name from Germanicus
column2: grandson of first Emperor Octavian Augustus

column1: The Crusaders sustained a great defeat near the city in 1098. It passed to the Turkic dynasty of the Karamanids and became a centre of the Avşar Turks in 1228. During the Karamanid period
column2: several of Ermenek's historical mosques were constructed

column1: It was later incorporated into the Ottoman Empire
column2: becoming part of the Karaman Province
column3: where it was the second most important town after Karaman itself.

column2: Germanicopolis became a suffragan bishopric of the Archdiocese of Seleucia in Isauria
column3: in the sway of the Patriarchate of Antioch.
